III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4108 Financing and audit.
Section (1) A licensee shall do all of the following:
Description (c) Demonstrate sufficient financing to assure that proper care of
residents is provided and that licensing rules are followed.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility is experiencing financial concerns.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via email on 2/13/25.
Complainant did not have any additional information.
Senior Auditor (SA) was interviewed via phone on 2/18/25 and
via video conference on 4/23/25. SA reported a financial
concerns memo is issued for a facility when there’s a trend of
negative results (decline in total net assets) two years in a row. SA
reported short-term liabilities can come due at any time, and the
facility must demonstrate they have necessary funds to pay off
their short-term liabilities. SA reported the facility’s financial audit
shows the facility has a large deficit in working capital in the
amount of a negative $1,802,205. SA noted the prior year’s
working capital was a positive $139,414. SA reported considering
the facility’s line of credit and mortgage as long-term liabilities
instead of short-term liabilities (like they’re documented in the
financial audit report), it reduces the facility’s short-term debt by
almost $2 million. SA reported the financial audit report did not
note the facility was negotiating their long-term debts, so he was
unaware of that information. SA reported the financial auditor
should have noted that information in the report. SA reported had
the facility’s line of credit and mortgage been listed under long-
term liabilities instead of short-term liabilities, there would not have
been any concerns noted from MDHHS’ auditing department and
no memo of financial concerns would have been issued.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 2/18/25. CA reported their fiscal year is from May 1st-
April 30th and they’re currently working on a new budget. CA
reported this is his fourth year as a director and he’s never had to
complete a corrective action plan regarding financial concerns or
because of a financial audit. CA reported the board approves all
finances and expenditures. CA reported the facility has never had
any financial issues regarding providing for or meeting the needs
of the residents. CA reported the facility is current on all their
debts and liabilities. CA reported the per diem rate for youth has
almost doubled over the years, so it has helped significantly. CA
2

reported they’re in a slight deficit for their residential budget
because their expenses have exceeded the money coming in.
However, CA reported they receive donations and funding from
their fund development which assists in covering any deficit they
have, so they never end in a deficit.
Finance Director (FD) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 2/18/25. FD reported working capital is the facility’s
current assets minus their current liabilities, which is listed as a
negative $1.8 million in the memo of financial concerns authored
by SA. FD reported most of that amount is their mortgage and
their line of credit. FD reported they drew a $700,000 line of credit
due to a delay in payments received from their funders, including
MDHHS. FD reported the presentation of their long-term liabilities
on the financial report changed placement in the report from 2023
to 2024. For example, in 2023, the facility’s mortgage was
documented under long-term liabilities, but in 2024, the facility’s
mortgage was documented under current liabilities. FD reported
their mortgage was listed under current liabilities for 2024 financial
audit report because they were re-negotiating their mortgage
contract (which is still ongoing due to an appraisal), and they had
not yet received the completed contract. FD reported they should
receive the newly approved mortgage contract by April 2025. FD
reported the mortgage is still considered a long-term liability, but
because the amount was reflected differently on the financial audit
report, it negatively affected their working capital. FD reported
they issue a financial statement every month, which is reviewed
and assessed by the executive board monthly, and finance
committee every other month. FD reported they are not behind on
any debts and would be ahead of financial requirements if they
were reimbursed by the State of Michigan timely. For example, as
of February 2025, the facility still has not received their unfilled
residential bed payment from October 2024. FD reported the
facility does not have any financial concerns right now and the
change in placement of information on the financial audit report
reflects a change in layout of information due to their current
mortgage negotiation but does not support financial concerns as
presented in the memo of financial concerns authored by SA.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Highfields, Inc. Audit Report for Fiscal Year Ended 4/30/24
(Memo of Financial Concerns) dated 2/12/25 authored by
SA notes the Compliance Monitoring Unit completed a
review of the above-referenced audit report. The memo
notes information about the facility’s decline in total net
assets, working capital, current ratio, and operating loss.
3

The most relevant information is related to the facility’s
working capital, which is documented to be a negative
$1,802,205. Negative working capital generally indicates
and agency’s inability to pay off its short-term liabilities if
they came due immediately. Prior year working capital was
a positive $139,414.
• Highfields, Inc. Report on Financial Statements (with
supplementary information) dated 7/22/24 (Financial Audit
Report). Page 4 of the report notes there are no long-term
debts for the facility in 2024 and lists all liabilities/debts
under “Current Liabilities”. This information is also
documented on page 20 of the Financial Audit report. Both
pages note the facility had long-term liabilities in 2023. The
Financial Audit report did not note any financial concerns
for the facility and did not require a corrective action plan.
• Letter to Highfields, Inc. authored by Dart Bank dated
1/30/25 outlines the terms and conditions discussed
regarding renewing the existing maturing mortgage loan for
the facility’s commercial mortgage loan.
• Corporate Resolution to Borrow/Grant
Collateral/Subordinate Debt authored by The Dart Bank
notes the facility’s mortgage loan was established on
3/31/25 and matures on 4/5/30.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, the mortgage loan has been
officially established, which puts the mortgage amount under long-
term liabilities instead of short-term liabilities, which in turn means
the facility no longer has a negative working capital. There are no
concerns regarding the facility’s ability to meet the needs of the
residential program and youth in the program.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
